discussion.content:
Treemap : Are charts of colored rectangles, with size representing value. They can be hierarchical, with rectangles nested within the main rectangles.

Key Influencer : A key influencer chart displays the major contributors to a selected result or value.
scatter : Display relationships between 2 (scatter) or 3 (bubble) quantitative measures -- whether or not, in which order, etc.

comments.content: Thanks!

discussion.content: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/visuals/power-bi-visualization-types-for-reports-and-q-and-a

Treemap: A treemap uses nested rectangles to represent data hierarchically, with each rectangle sized and colored based on its value.
Key Influencer: A key influencer chart identifies the factors that have the most significant impact on a selected outcome, showing the major contributors.
Scatter: A scatter plot displays the relationship between two numerical variables, often revealing trends, clusters, or correlations.

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Tree map -
Treemaps are charts of colored rectangles, with size representing value. They can be hierarchical, with rectangles nested within the main rectangles.


Box 2: Key influencer -
A key influencer chart displays the major contributors to a selected result or value.

Box 3: Scatter -
Scatter and Bubble charts display relationships between 2 (scatter) or 3 (bubble) quantitative measures -- whether or not, in which order, etc.

discussion.content: shouldn't this be OLAP?

comments.content:
Quality assurance application focuses on improving the software development process and making it efficient and effective as per quality standards.

OLAP applies complex queries to large amounts of historical data, aggregated from OLTP databases and other sources, for data mining, analytics, and business intelligence projects.
Moreover, the purpose of OLAP ----> Plan, solve problems, support decisions, discover hidden insights.

According to the question, the application is reading data from the data warehouse for quality assurance which is clearly - discovering insights from the data. Thus, the answer is OLAP.

Agree.
Quality assurance need to test a Datawarehouse by using OLAP processing.

discussion.content: OLAP make more sense
option C

Selected Answer: C
The quality assurance application that reads data from a data warehouse typically uses Online Analytical Processing (OLAP) because it involves querying and analyzing historical data for reporting and analysis purposes. OLAP is optimized for complex queries and aggregations on large volumes of data, making it suitable for tasks like data analysis and business intelligence, which align with quality assurance activities. So, the correct answer is:
C. Online Analytical Processing (OLAP)
c is correct

OLAP processing is specifically designed for analytical operations on large volumes of data. It involves performing complex queries, aggregations, and calculations on the data to gain insights and make informed decisions. In the context of a quality assurance application, OLAP processing allows for the analysis of data from the data warehouse to identify patterns, trends, and anomalies, and to generate reports and visualizations for quality assessment and improvement purposes.

Selected Answer: C
Online Analytical Processing (OLAP) - as per Chat GPT
C. Online Analytical Processing (OLAP) -- As per Chat GPT
C is correct
Data Warehouse OLAP

Selected Answer: C
The quality assurance application that reads data from a data warehouse likely uses online analytical processing (OLAP).

Online analytical processing (OLAP) is a category of software tools that enables users to analyze data from multiple dimensions and levels of detail. This type of processing is typically used for business intelligence, data mining, and reporting applications. The data is typically stored in a data warehouse or a multidimensional database, and the OLAP system allows users to perform complex queries and calculations on the data to generate insights and reports.
https://sqlwizardblog.wordpress.com/2020/03/15/sql-server-oltp-vs-olap/

The most important difference between OLTP and OLAP is that OLAP is implemented for reading big amounts of data for data analysis, whereas OLTP is designed for many parallel write transactions.

OLTP as this is data reading for application

I believe the key word is "reads", that means it reads and use the data form internal applications process, an online analytical process (OLAP). You don't have a transaction process where the application reads data from the DW, process it and write something back, because the application don't have write permissions.

Further OLTP stands for "Transaction Processing". The question clearly states that it is reading data from a Data Warehouse, which is not a "Transaction Processing" system. Usually "Transaction Processing" has frequent reads, which a DW does not have.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/data-guide/relational-data/online-transaction-processing#challenges This article implies OLAP for Data Warehouses.
OLAP makes more sense
